title: 110_hr634
content:
The "American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes the service and sacrifices of disabled veterans and those who made the ultimate sacrifice for their country. It honors all veterans who have defended the principles of democracy, including those who carry the scars of war every day. The American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act authorizes the minting of a commemorative silver dollar coin to honor living disabled veterans and raise funds for the construction of the American Veterans Disabled for Life Memorial. The coin specifications include a weight of 26.73 grams, a diameter of 1.500 inches, and a composition of 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. The coins minted under the American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act are legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins should symbolize the service of disabled veterans, with specific inscriptions and design requirements outlined. The American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act specifies the design selection process and quality of coins to be minted, with a preference for striking them at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may issue coins under this Act only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010. The coins shall be sold at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before the coins are issued. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.
All sales of coins issued under this Act shall include a surcharge of $10 per coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation for the construction of American Veterans' Disabled for Life Memorial in Washington, D.C. The Comptroller General of the United States will audit the Foundation's expenditures related to these funds. No surcharge may exceed $10 per coin. No surcharge may be included for issuing any coin under this Act if it would exceed the annual commemorative coin program limit. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide guidance on this limitation.
